Executive Summary:



(a)    The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy:

Agri-Mark/Cabot's policy is to provide a place of employment free from recognized hazards that could cause injury or illness, including serious physical or medical conditions or death to any director, officer, employee, consultant, contractor or visitor and to fully comply with both OSHA and state, health and safety standards. Among other things, these standards may require employees to wear appropriate protection, adhere to all Company safety and hazardous material policies and practices including emergency response and require Agri-Mark/Cabot to provide proper training and supervision. We expect all directors, officers, employees, consultants, contractors, or visitors, to comply with all safety requirements.



Agri-Mark/Cabot constantly strives to improve its safety program to reduce risks and eliminate and/or minimize potential injuries, accidents and releases. Agri-Mark/Cabot's goal is to train employees to recognize unsafe behaviors, to encourage safe behaviors, and to be actively involved in the safety process. An ongoing effort to provide a safe working environment for all employees is a major concern of the Companies. It is important for all employees to become more actively involved in day today safety awareness, particularly as it applies to their individual jobs. Agri-Mark/Cabot's goal is for employees to actively participate in the safety process, actively care about fellow employees, and to take corrective actions, as well as taking ownership of their individual safety.



(b) The Stationary Source and Substance Handled: 

Agri-Mark owns and operates the Middlebury facility, located at 869 Exchange Street, which produces cheese and other dairy related products. The purpose of the anhydrous ammonia used in the process is as a heat transfer medium for the facility's refrigeration system.



 (c) General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific P

revention Steps:  

Agri-Mark has implemented a comprehensive program to safely manage anhydrous ammonia at the Agri-Mark, Middlebury facility located at 869 Exchange Street in Middlebury, Vermont.



Based on the Risk Management Program, Program Level applicability provisions, the covered process at the Agri-Mark, Middlebury facility meets the criteria of a Program Level 3 process.

The Agri-Mark, Middlebury facility has developed an accidental release prevention program and implemented chemical-specific prevention steps to manage the covered process.  The program includes both a documented compliance manual and administrative procedures to manage the program.  Specific elements of the program include, but are not limited to:



- A documented management system

- Completion of routine hazard assessments, including an offsite consequence analysis

- Assembly and retention of anhydrous ammonia safety information and other process safety information

- A process hazard analysis program to evaluate the controls and safeguards of the process

- Written standard operating procedures for anhydrous ammonia management and operations

- A written training program for the risk management program, inclusive of applicable operating, maintenance, and emergency response procedures

- A anhydrous ammonia system, mechanical integrity program

- A management of change process to evaluate process changes

- A pre-start-up safety review program to review applicable process changes

- A system for routine compliance audits, inclusive of third-party audits, as applicable

- A written incident investigation program

- A written employee participation program to involve applicable employees in the program

- A hot work permit program, inclusive of hot work permits

- A contractor selection and evaluation program 

- A written emergency response program

- A documented Risk Management Plan



In addition to the covered process, accidental release prevention program, the facility has an ac

tive safety program, involving all site personnel.  All employees have the authority to stop work if deemed unsafe and report the unsafe condition to their Supervisor.



Employees receive training on Personal Protective Equipment; Hazard Communication; Emergency Action Plan; Accident/Near Misses; Lock Out/tag Out; Confined Space among many other safety training topics.



(d) Five Year Accident History:  

There have been no accidental releases meeting the definition contained in 40 CFR ?68.42(a) within the last five years of operation.



(e) The Emergency Response Program: 

The Agri-Mark, Middlebury facility has developed a comprehensive Emergency Response Plan. The plan addresses fires, explosions, spills or releases of hazardous chemicals (including anhydrous ammonia), severe weather, and other potential emergency conditions. The plan details response actions by facility personnel for such emergencies, safety and emergency equipment, communication responsibilities, and coordination with off-site responders, as well as notification of local, state, and federal agencies.



The Emergency Response Plan includes emergency response to anhydrous ammonia releases. Should an emergency release of anhydrous ammonia occur at the facility, the facility will be evacuated, the Middlebury Fire Department will be notified, and the Fire Department will assume Incident Command.



(f) Planned Changes to Improve Safety: 

The Agri-Mark, Middlebury facility completed its most recent Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Compliance Audit in the first quarter of 2019. As a result of the PHA and Compliance Audit, a number of improvements to the risk management program have either been completed or are planned.  The improvements are intended to improve the safety of the process and minimize the potential for a release.
